--- title: "3.5 — Marshallian Economics II: Cost & Supply — Class Content" execute: freeze: auto --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"} # Meeting Dates *Tuesday, November 1, 2022* ::: ## Overview Today we continue the marginalist revolution. ## Readings ### Required Readings - Finish Ch.10 "Alfred Marshall and Neoclassical Economics" in Landreth & Colander - Ch.10 "Marshallian Economics: Cost and Supply" in Blaug ### Recommended Readings: - [ Marshall, Alfred, 1920 (1890), *Principles of Economics* (8th ed.)](https://www.econlib.org/library/Marshall/marP.html) The following Wikipedia entries can also provide more background: - [ Alfred Marshall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Marshall) - [ Tax incidence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tax_incidence) - [ Long run and short run](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_run_and_short_run) - [ Fixed cost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixed_cost) - [ Variable cost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variable_cost) - [ Cost curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost_curve) - [ Quasi-rent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasi-rent) - [ Economies of scale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economies_of_scale) - [ Economies of scale in Marshall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economies_of_scale#Economies_of_scale_in_Marshall) - [ Quantity Theory of Money (Cambridge Approach)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantity_theory_of_money#Cambridge_approach) ### Questions to Help Your Reading - What are the four “periods” (or “runs”) according to Marshall? What is different about the supply curve in each? - What do you recognize from your principles & intermediate microeconomics courses from Marshall? - What is a “quasi-rent”? Why does it only exist in the short run? - What is a constant-cost, increasing-cost, and decreasing-cost industry? - What are interval vs. external economies of scale? What are the implications for competition vs. monopoly? - How does Marshall’s view of money and the quantity theory differ from Fisher? ### Questions to Help Your Reading ## Slides Below, you can find the slides in two formats. Clicking the image will bring you to the html version of the slides in a new tab. The lower button will allow you to download a PDF version of the slides. ::: callout-tip You can type h to see a special list of viewing options, and type o for an outline view of all the slides. ::: I suggest printing the slides beforehand and using them to take additional notes in class (*not everything* is in the slides)!

Download as PDF

## Assignments ### Participation/Discussion Board Posts Due 8 PM Fri Nov 4 This week's graded discussion is worth 5 points, and can be a combination of discussion in class, and/or posts on the Blackboard Discussion Board by 8 PM this Friday November 4. ## Tournament Votes The first round of the Classical division of the "Most Interesting Economist in History" tournament is live. Please post your votes in the discussion board.
